Point¶

class Point¶

A point in a two-dimensional plane.

__init__(x, y)¶

Creates a new Point object from Cartesian coordinates.

Parameters:

  • x – the x-coordinate of the point

  • y – the y-coordinate of the point

property x¶

The x-coordinate of the point.

property y¶

The y-coordinate of the point.

__add__(other)¶

Add this point to another point with vector addition. (In other words, the individual coordinates are added.)

>>> Point(1, 2) + Point(3, 4)
Point(4, 6)
Parameters:

other (Point) – the point to add

Returns:

the result of the addition

__sub__(other)¶

Subtract two points with vector subtraction. (In other words, the individual coordinates are subtracted.)

>>> Point(1, 2) - Point(3, 4)
Point(-2, -2)
Parameters:

other (Point) – the point to subtract

Returns:

the result of the subtraction

__mul__(scale)¶

Scale this point up from the origin by a certain scale factor. (In other words, each coordinate is multiplied by scale.)

>>> Point(1, 2) * 3
Point(3, 6)
Parameters:

scale – the scale factor

Returns:

the result of the multiplication

__rmul__(scale)¶

Equivalent to __mul__(), but in the reverse order.

>>> 3 * Point(1, 2)
Point(3, 6)
Parameters:

scale – the scale factor

Returns:

the result of the multiplication

__truediv__(scale)¶

Scale this point down from the origin by a certain scale factor. (In other words, each coordinate is divided by scale.)

>>> Point(3, 6) / 3
Point(1.0, 2.0)
Parameters:

scale – the scale factor

Returns:

the result of the division

__neg__()¶

Rotate this point by 180 degrees about the origin. Equivalent to negating both coordinates.

>>> -Point(1, 2)
Point(-1, -2)
Returns:

the negated point

__pos__()¶

Return this point.

>>> +Point(1, 2)
Point(1, 2)
Returns:

the same point

__abs__()¶

Return the Euclidean distance from this point to the origin.

>>> abs(Point(3, -4))
5.0
Returns:

the distance from the point to the origin

__repr__()¶

Return string representation of this point.

Returns:

string representation of this point

__str__()¶

Return string representation of this point, but formatted like a tuple.

>>> print(Point(1, 2))
(1, 2)
Returns:

string representation of this point, formatted like tuple

__eq__(other)¶

Returns whether or not two points are located at the same place in the Cartesian plane. (Internally, this function uses math.isclose.)

>>> Point(3, 4) - Point(1, 1) == Point(2, 3)
True
Parameters:

other (Point) – the point to test for equality

Returns:

whether or not the two points are located at the same place

dist(other)¶

Return the Euclidean distance from this point to other. Equivalent to abs(other-self).

>>> Point(2, 3).dist(Point(5, 7))
5.0
Parameters:

other (Point) – the point to take the distance to

Returns:

the computed distance

dot(other)¶

Return the dot product of this vector and other.

>>> Point(2, 6).dot(Point(5, 2))
22
Parameters:

other (Point) – the point to dot with

Returns:

the dot product

cross(other)¶

Return the magnitude of the cross product of this vector and other. A positive result indicates that the cross product points upwards from the plane, while a negative result indicates the opposite.

>>> Point(2, 6).cross(Point(5, 2))
-26
Parameters:

other (Point) – the point to cross with

Returns:

the cross product
